title: Stenbury Trail Walking Route

images.title: Shaun Ferguson, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Off the Shanklin road the Stenbury trail heading up to Godshill Park house.

images.title: Shaun Ferguson / Public Bridleway A22
images.caption: Public Bridleway A22 part of Stenbury trail heading to Great Budbridge Manor.

images.title: Graham Horn / Dual cabbageways near NCN23
images.caption: Dual cabbageways near NCN23. The minor land followed by National Cycle Route 23 is on the left. It is also used by the Stenbury Trail, one of a mosaic of marked footpath routes on the Isle Of Wight. The crops, pairs of lines, are just starting to show through? What are they? I hope they are cabbages then children looking at this picture can call them "dual cabbageways".

images.title: Shaun Ferguson / Cycleway on dismantled railway
images.caption: Cycleway and Stenbury Trail on dismantled railway nearing the crossing on Blackwater Hollow

images.title: Simon Carey / Stenbury Down
images.caption: Stenbury Down. At the point where a track ascending from the valley floor meets the bridleway that runs along the ridge of the Downs. The track is a maintenance road for the two sets of masts at the summit of the downs. The bridleway continues south to Ventnor.

images.title: Christine Matthews / Appuldurcombe House, Isle of Wight
images.caption: Appuldurcombe House, Isle of Wight. The House is the shell of a large 18th-century English Baroque country house of the Worsley family. It's located near to Wroxall and is now managed by English Heritage.

images.title: Stenbury Trail towards Newport by Ian S, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Stenbury Trail towards Newport

images.title: Ventnor Botanic Garden by David Dixon, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Ventnor Botanic Garden. A lovely place for a stroll at the end of the route. The Mediterranean style gardens include a number of interesting plants which are generally considered too tender for much of mainland Britain.

description: This trail follows bridleways along the river valley from Newport, passing Appuldurcombe, Stenbury and Week Downs before finishing at the delightful Ventnor botanic gardens on the coast. The walk involves a decent climb but you are rewarded with fabulous views of the island and coast. Highlights include the thatched cottages in the pretty village of Godshill and the English Heritage owned Appuldurcombe House .
